item.title: Laws and Morality
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

When you’re born into a country governed by a state you signed an unconditional contract (the social contract) in which you give up some of your freedom in order for the state to protect your civil liberties (such as stopping people from killing and stealing from you), so yes, I think that the law should enforce situations that breeches the rights of other people’s civil liberties, the fundamental problem is who decides what is and what is not moral, the Mayans sacrificed people to their gods and yet they felt it was necessary, by today’s standards it would be considered completely barbaric but to them it was ethical. And my answer to that, is that any action that directly influences someone else’s right to civil liberties (providing they’re part of the state) should be punished through legal enforcement (by the state).

item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

m1lkman:

So anything that you do that interferes with another’s right should be made illegal?

It all depends on perspective. Is a government that puts down some basic laws concerning safety in the workplace and traffic interfering with peoples rights, or is it just concerned about safety?

Besides, safety isn’t just a personal matter. If you are involved in a car crash, and you sustain brain damage because you didn’t wear safety belts, society is a victim too. Because of your brain damage, you won’t be able to work to your full potential, and you receive some form of social security. So the economy doesn’t benefit from you, the government doesn’t raise (as much) taxes, and the government has to pay you money. Nobody wins.

item.title: Laws and Morality
item.dc:creator: @TheCyberMan TheCyberMan
item.description:
@TheCyberMan wrote:

A government’s role should not be to enforce morality, but to effectively run a civilization within reason (these reasons are the very basic standards of living that have been accepted since the advent of society, such as no killing and no stealing). Additionally, I believe a government should enforce its rule of law.

However, if the government becomes too involved, moral decisions influence political decisions, which affects individuals differently. For example, many moral decisions involve safety, such as having to wear a helmet while riding a motorcycle. In this case, safety outweighs liberty, but should the government necessarily tell me how to protect myself? If I kill myself, that’s on me, not the general public.

Just some food for thought
